newsitem.title: USA: Plains feedlot cattle market seen quiet - trade.
newsitem.headline: Plains feedlot cattle market seen quiet - trade.

text.p: Plains feedlot cattle markets were expected to remain quiet Friday, following this week's record-setting heavy volume, feedlot sources said.

The bulk of this week's sales took place Tuesday at $68.00 per cwt, up $2.00 from the previous week, but many showlists were lighter by then because of active sales late last week and finished the week practically depleted, they said.
Those cattle not sold were being priced at $69.00 to $70.00, but considered too 'green' or unfinished, while packer inquiry was light, with a few bids at $68.00.

USDA confirmed sales on 155,000 head for the week to date through midday Thursday in the Texas Panhandle/western Oklahoma area, which broke the previous record high of 136,800 the week ended Feb 22 this year, USDA said.
Week-to-date sales in Kansas were pegged at 130,700 head, which snapped the previous record high of 115,059 set the week ended July 28, 1995, according to USDA.
Feedlot cattle prices also were buoyed by a bounce in wholesale boxed beef prices this week, market sources said.
